titleStmt.title: such a thing as ownership
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Because the manuscript has not been located it is difficult to speculate on the circumstances or date of its composition, but Edward Grier dates it to the early 1850s, noting that "the idea expressed is one that occupied [Whitman's] mind" as he prepared the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. Grier also notes that this manuscript may have been part of an early notebook.

biblStruct.note: Grier derives his text from Walt Whitman's Workshop, ed. Clifton J. Furness (Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1928), 45.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: such a thing as ownership
bibl.orgName: The location of this manuscript is unknown.

body.ab: such a thing as ownership here anyhow—one of the laws being that from the moment a man takes the smallest page exclusively to himself, and tries to keep it from the rest, from that moment it begins to wither under his hand and its immortal hieroglyphics presently fade away and become blank.
